Award.AwardTitle: Trends and Variability of Temperatures near the Tropical Tropopause Layer and Implications for Tropical Cyclones
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will enhance understanding of atmospheric physics, chemistry, and dynamics on tropical cyclone activity. It will advance scientific confidence in projections of the influence of climate change on tropical cyclones. Linkages across chemistry, radiation, dynamics, and meteorology provide an ideal framework for the type of cross-disciplinary education needed for the next generation of climate scientists.

Understanding of the factors that influence tropical cyclones has broadened in recent years to include consideration of the tropical tropopause layer (TTL), which can affect storm outflow temperatures and thereby potential and actual intensities. Observations from multiple sources show that the atmosphere in the vicinity of the TTL exhibits substantial variability on interannual and decadal timescales, which could affect variability and trends in tropical cyclones. However, the physical and chemical processes affecting these changes are not well understood, and reanalysis products and coupled general circulation models often do not agree on the magnitude of this variability. The effects of changes in volcanic aerosol, water vapor, and ozone in a hierarchy of radiative and chemical/dynamical modeling approaches will be examined, and implications of radiative processes for tropical cyclones will be identified.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our NSF project addressed the interesting and important question of how natural and manmade climate change might affect the frequency and behavior of tropical cyclones (aka hurricanes). While interest has been mostly focused on the intensity and frequency of storms, we looked at trends in where these storms reach their peak intensity. The accompanying figure, from our Nature paper, shows that the latitude of peak intensity has been migrating away from the equator, as revealed by satellite measurements. This is consistent with expectations about how global warming might affect these storms.

Much previous work has looked at how the temperatures of tropical oceans affect the intensity of tropical cyclones. But these storms are giant heat engines, whose efficiency depends, among other things, on how low the temperature is at the top of the storm, where the heat extracted from the ocean is exported to the storms’ environment. The colder the storm top is, the stronger the storm (all other things being equal). This is predicted by theory and confirmed using computer models. The storm top temperature is closely related to the temperature of the tropopause…the boundary between the troposphere (where most weather happens) and the dry stratosphere above it. The tropical tropopause is quite cold….below -100 degrees Fahrenheit.

We found that the temperature of the tropopause over the North Atlantic, where hurricanes form, has been decreasing over the past few decades; yet elsewhere we could find no significant trends. The downward trend in tropopause temperature over the North Atlantic has made an important contribution to the increasing “potential intensity” of hurricanes. The “potential intensity” is a theoretical upper limit on hurricane wind speeds, given the temperature of the atmosphere and the underlying ocean. Although we could find no significant trends in potential intensity outside the North Atlantic, we did find that much of the year-to-year changes in potential intensity all through the tropics can be traced to fluctuations in the tropopause temperature.

We also tried to discover why the tropopause has been cooling over the North Atlantic, and what has been causing the year-to-year fluctuations of tropopause temperature there and elsewhere in the tropics. We found that large volcanic eruptions cause a warming of the tropopause over the North Atlantic that last about two years; thus we think that big volcanoes might suppress Atlantic hurricane activity for a few years.  Curiously, we could not find much signal of the volcanoes elsewhere. We also found that a slow, large-scale ascent that prevails in the lower tropical stratosphere – a circulation known as the “Brewer-Dobson Circulation” – has been increasing over the past few decades; this may be related to the cooling of the tropopause over the North Atlantic since upward motion tends to cool the atmosphere. But we also found that temperatures in the lower stratosphere have been significantly affected by changes in water vapor, ozone, carbon dioxide, and aerosol particles, all of which affect the absorption and emission of radiation in the atmosphere.

Finally, we found that the seasonal cycle of temperatures near the tropopause plays a significant role in the seasonal cycle of tropical cyclone activity. The waxing and waning of hurricanes over the course of a year is not simply a matter of surface temperatures changing but is also influenced by temperatures high above the surface.
